Chapter 2 Bookdown Notes 2.1 Number and reference equations

Chapter 2 Bookdown Notes 2.1 Number and reference equations Note: I copied this section from Authoring Books with R Markdown. More tips can be found there! To number and refer to equations, put them in the equation environments and assign labels to them using the syntax (\#eq:label), e.g., \begin{equation} f\left(k\right) = \binom{n}{k} p^k\left(1-p\right)^{n-k} (\#eq:binom) \end{equation} It renders the equation below: \[\begin{equation} f\left(k\right) = \binom{n}{k} p^k\left(1-p\right)^{n-k} \tag{2.1} \end{equation}\] You may refer to it using \@ref(eq:binom), e.g., see Equation (2.1).

Chapter 3 General tips about R programming 3.1 Manipulating Dates 3.1.1 Day of year (DOY) and Date Conversion # note that R uses a 0 based index for dates only # this means it starts counting at 0 rather than 1 when working with dates as.Date(0, origin = "2016-01-01") ## [1] "2016-01-01" # note that R uses a 0 based index as.Date(1, origin = "2016-01-01") ## [1] "2016-01-02" # figure out the date for day 189 as.Date(189, origin = "2016-01-01") ## [1] "2016-07-08" The lubridate package can make some conversions easier. lubridate::as_date("2021-01-01") ## [1] "2021-01-01" # find today's the DOY lubridate::yday(Sys.time()) ## [1] 113 3.2 data.table Frequently Asked Questions about data.table 3.3 Format numbers and digits Add leading/ending zeros to a number, it can be done using formatC and sprintf. num <- c(0, 1, 10, 1.1, 2.34) formatC(num, width = 4, format = "d", flag = "0") ## [1] "0000" "0001" "0010" "0001" "0002" formatC(num, digits = 3, format = "f", flag = "0") ## [1] "0.000" "1.000" "10.000" "1.100" "2.340" 3.4 Progress bar I copied the some example code from: R: Monitoring the function progress with a progress bar Text based progress bar: total <- 20 # create progress bar pb <- txtProgressBar(min = 0, max = total, style = 3) for (i in 1:total) { Sys.sleep(0.1) # update progress bar setTxtProgressBar(pb, i) } close(pb) A GUI progress bar from tcltk package: total <- 20 # create progress bar pb <- tcltk::tkProgressBar( title = "progress bar", min = 0, max = total, width = 300 ) for (i in 1:total) { Sys.sleep(0.1) tcltk::setTkProgressBar(pb, i, label = paste( round(i / total * 100, 0), "% done" )) } close(pb) A progress bar using the Windows operating system: total <- 20 # create progress bar pb <- winProgressBar( title = "progress bar", label = "Progress", # must provide label here, otherwise it won't show in the update label min = 0, max = total, width = 300 ) for (i in 1:total) { Sys.sleep(0.1) setWinProgressBar(pb, i, label = paste( round(i / total * 100, 0), "% done" )) } close(pb) 3.5 Dealing with files and paths filename <- "some_folder/some_example_file.txt" # get the file extension tools::file_ext(filename) ## [1] "txt" # get the file name without extension tools::file_path_sans_ext(filename) ## [1] "some_folder/some_example_file" tools::file_path_sans_ext(basename(filename)) ## [1] "some_example_file" # get the file path. # it'll search for the file in the current working directory and return the full path. # tools::file_path_as_absolute(filename)

Chapter 4 Notes for R plots 4.1 Plotting rasters using raster package This section refered this website 4.1.1 Arguments for plotting rasters The arguments used in raster packages plot function: raster plot arguments Common tweaks: raster plot tweaks The plot function also supports: - Horizontal legend bar - Zooming in to an extent of the raster - Interpolation of the raster plot - Use zlim to plot several raster images with the same scale and a single legend Additionally, rasterVis package provides useful raster plotting functions (check this website). 4.2 Customize the appearance of plots 4.2.1 Axis Sometimes theres not enough space for R to show all axis labels, e.g., beacause the figure is too narrow, R would hide some axis labels but this is not we want. If the figure width/height can be changed or if the axis labels can be rotated using las parameter, thats fine. But sometimes, the labels are not long texts, we believe showing them all wouldnt make them overlap with each other. In this case, we could reduce the gap between labels to force R showing all axis labels. We can use gap.axis parameter to achieve this goal. gap.axis works for the manual axis() function as well as some plot functions such as boxplot(). Normally, I would use gap.axis = 0.01 as the value to plot x axis labels.
